item.title: [IN-93] Can DLT help with reliable private data transfer between departments across government?
item.description:
Summary

A private or permissioned blockchain could enable organisations and departments to quickly configure and run a distributed ledger capable of distributing data between each other. This experiment aims to determine how to run a government-maintained interdepartmental ledger that could provide value to multiple departments needing access to the same data with several different products.

Nature of research in this pack

The insight from this experiment may prove the usefulness of investment in a specific technology in the medium term, in addition to bigger, wider reaching projects in the long term. It is worth noting that distributed ledger technology is still young, and as such, improvements and new use cases surface regularly.

Problem

Multiple government departments are often required to exchange information between each other, where frequently, there may be dependencies on the data, impacting day to day operations or decisions being made. Traditional forms of IT data exchange may carry overheads and, without the proper support, the potential for error, miscommunication or leaks.

Hypothesis

A private or permissioned blockchain could be created to facilitate the sharing of data, and improvement of security all while reducing error, fraud, costs, and the risks associated with other means of data sharing. Having access to shared data would allow government departments to more easily conduct day to day operations and make decisions.

Experiment and research proposed

Setup a Docker cluster where each node represents a government department capable of reading and writing data that is restricted to and made immediately available to other departments.
item.summary: Can DLT help with reliable private data transfer between departments across government?

$.description: This issue is being actively worked on at the moment by the assignee.

comment._: "private or permissioned": is that inclusive or exclusive (sorry English is ambiguous

item.title: [IN-8] Can Eris provide a X-Gov blockchain for private data sharing?
item.description:
Summary

It is not possible to know when Multichain will come out of beta and Ethereum does not have the ability to run private chains. It is believed that Eris which is designed to provide a way of managing Blockchains will enable us to stand up a set of nodes on a private network that will not try and connect to a public network and share its data?
item.summary: Can Eris provide a X-Gov blockchain for private data sharing?

$.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

item.title: [IN-118] Could BigChainDB solve Master Data Management in Microservices?
item.description:
Summary

In a MicroServices architecture where each service is self contained and has its own datastore it is easy for various copies of the same Information to become slightly out of sync. This normally results in some form of Master Data Management tooling which periodically goes in and fixes inconsistencies. As BigChainDB uses Blockchain characteristics to ensure that all copies of a datastore are exactly the same all the time could this reduce the requirement for a Master Data Management tool?
item.summary: Could BigChainDB solve Master Data Management in Microservices?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-1] Bootstrap Ethereum Blockhain
item.description:
Original white paper from Vitalik Butarin: http://vbuterin.com/ethereum.html
Technical yellow paper from Gavin Wood: http://gavwood.com/Paper.pdf

Current Ethereum white paper: https://github.com/ethereum/wiki/wiki/White-Paper
item.summary: Bootstrap Ethereum Blockhain

$.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comment._:
https://www.ethereum.org/

A public blockchain platform with support for smart contracts. Currently surrounded by a lot of hype and excitement.

Intention is to build a platform that will allow others to develop decentralised applications on top. The smart contract implementation provides a turing-complete programming language. Ethereum provides its own currency on the network, and computing power (execution of smart contracts) is paid for using the this currency.

All smart contracts are executed on every full Ethereum node, resulting in consensus of the output. Some useful discussion here

Unlike Bitcoin, there is no cap on the total amount of the Ethereum currency (ETH). Currently, mining uses the Proof of Work algorithm with plans to switch to a Proof of Stake system called Casper. This requires more research! Describe both mechanisms thoroughly, lists pros and cons, and try to attain a solid understanding of Casper, too.

In addition to the native ETH currency, one can build custom cryptocurrencies, or tokens to represent whatever they want. Similar to the example we've used for MultiChain - you could have a NIC token, or different tokens representing various taxes or benefit types.

From Vitalik's white paper:

  • "The concept of a transaction having multiple inputs and outputs, for example, is gone, replaced by a more intuitive balance-based model"
  • "Unlike other cryptocurrencies, which aim to have "features", Ethereum intends to take features away, and instead provide its users with near-infinite power through an all-encompassing mechanism called "'contracts'"
  • "The Ethereum network includes its own built-in currency, ether. The main reason for including a currency in the network is twofold. First, like Bitcoin, ether is rewarded to miners to as to incentivize network security. Second, it serves as a mechanism for paying transaction fees for anti-spam purposes"
  • "The nonce is the number of transactions made from the address, and is incremented every time a transaction is made."

Double spend, AKA transaction replay attacks are prevented by storing an incrementing nonce (the number of transactions made from an address) against the account balance.

The Proof of Work system currently used in Ethereum uses an algorithm called Dagger to use a large amount of memory in addition to a large amount of processing power when mining.
Ethereum channel on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/ethereumproject

What is Ethereum? https://ethereum.gitbooks.io/frontier-guide/content/ethereum.html

In a technical sense, Ethereum is a "world computer". Harking back to the days of the mainframe, and probably about as fast, Ethereum can be viewed as a single computer that the whole world can use. It notionally has only a single processor (no multi-threading or parallel execution), but as much memory as required. Anybody can upload programs to the Ethereum World Computer and anybody can request that a program that has been uploaded be executed. This does not mean that anyone can ask any program to do anything; on the contrary: the author of the program can specify that requests from anyone but themselves be ignored, for example. Also, in a very strong sense, every program has its own permanent storage that persists between executions. Furthermore, as long as it is in demand, the Ethereum World Computer will always be there: it can't be shut down or turned off.

In Ethereum, there are two types of entities that can generate/receive transactions: bots/people (indistinguishable), and contracts.

A contract is essentially an automated agent that lives on the Ethereum network, has an Ethereum address and balance, and can send and receive transactions. A contract is "activated" every time someone sends a transaction to it, at which point it runs its code
Ethereum Stack Exchange site (useful for support): http://ethereum.stackexchange.com/
Some pros and cons of Ethereum's account balance approach vs Bitcoin's UTXO: http://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/326/what-are-the-pros-and-cons-of-ethereum-balances-vs-utxos

Some additional info on Ethereum:

  • a global state stores a list of accounts with balances, code, and internal storage
  • a transaction is valid if the sending account has enough balance to pay for it, in which case the sending account is debited and the receiving account is credited with the value
  • if the receiving account has code, the code runs, and internal storage may also be changed, or the code may even create additional messages to other accounts which lead to further debits and credits

GHOST protocol white paper (technical): https://eprint.iacr.org/2013/881.pdf
http://www.cs.huji.ac.il/~avivz/pubs/13/btc_scalability_full.pdf

Ethereum uses a partial implementation of GHOST. Good explanation here: http://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/314/what-is-ghost-and-what-is-its-relationship-to-frontier-and-casper

and here: https://github.com/ethereum/wiki/wiki/White-Paper#modified-ghost-implementation

Summary of GHOST protocol:

  • Greedy Heaviest Observed Subtree
  • Blockchains with fast confirmation times suffer from reduced security due to a high stale rate
    • Larger mining pools will also produce stale blocks less frequently than smaller pools / individuals
    • This can lead (in chains with fast confirmation times) to a scenario where having a large enough share of the hashing power on the network will give de facto control over the mining process
  • GHOST includes stale blocks in the calculation of which chain is "longest", referred to as "uncles" in Ethereum
  • Ethereum only counts stale blocks up to N generations to reduce complexity

Note: GHOST can be considered an alternative solution to the problem MultiChain's round-robin approach attempts to solve.

Question: what are the implications of a move away from PoW to a PoS model? Will GHOST continue to be used?

Started to bootstrap Ethereum. Docker configuration can be found here: https://github.com/stevebakh/docker-ethereum

note: this is a WIP.
Made some solid progress with the bootstrapping. Now have some docker compose configuration that will run an arbitrary number of nodes that should connect to one another.

This page would indicate that smart contract code is executed at the point a miner adds the transaction to a block.

https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Contracts-and-Transactions

When this transaction gets included in a block, somewhere on a lucky miner's computer, 6 will get multiplied by 7, with the result ignored. Mission accomplished.
reopened due to change in workflow

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Have successfully followed bootstrap to create a working chain for my self

item.title: [IN-117] Can DLT make low-fi calendar availability easier between partners?
item.description:
When working with other organisations, a pain point is coordinating times. Formal federation is practical for some situations and Doodle et al have provided a great light-weight integration but with DLT there could be a nice middle ground: nominated calendar visibility that connects loosely with existing calendars perhaps via ical updates.

It matches perfectly with the classic use case of DLT: optional contribution to a shared resource.
item.summary: Can DLT make low-fi calendar availability easier between partners?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-116] Can smart contracts improve efficiency and effectiveness of our customer services where we have legal contracts today?
item.summary: Can smart contracts improve efficiency and effectiveness of our customer services where we have legal contracts today?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comment._: Smart Contracts are not considered a replacement for legal contracts, almost all products implementing them make this clear. The reason is that executing code is absolute whereas executing legal contracts is not.

Good to know. So what is a good statement of what problem smart contracts attempt to solve? The O2 demo of R3 / Corda seemed to show traceability between a contract and some code. Guidance most welcome.

So if a legal contract is automated then a blockchain smart contract is useful but not all legal contracts can be automated. So if you skim read this article http://www.coindesk.com/barclays-smart-contracts-templates-demo-r3-corda/ you will note that the process registers the agreement between to parties onto the blockchain but doesn't automate it. this becomes an immutable record of agreements between parties.

So I guess the question would become 'can a Blockchain provide a more efficient method of recognising or validating the legal agreements between parties?'

item.title: [IN-23] Could RFID or NFC tags combined with a Blockchain provide a robust system for identifying owners or locations of misplaced equipment?
item.description:
Summary

Electronic Asset Management through Smart asset tags (RFID or NFC) could be used to link a statement of ownership on a Blockchain. This would mean that a simple scan of an Smart tag could identify the correct owner, possibly with the right infrastructure you could actually track the location of equipment within a building in order to locate it.

Questions

Are RFID or NFC tags secure enough, can they used when stuck inside devices out of sight.

Notes

It is understood that tags can be removed and replaced but if they can help locate missing devices or identify expected owners it may have a valuable proposition
item.summary: Could RFID or NFC tags combined with a Blockchain provide a robust system for identifying owners or locations of misplaced equipment?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-45] Could a DLT foster a X-Gov social capital data exchange?
item.description: Internal App similar to Kudos: Peer-to-peer acknowledgement tool for employees to acknowledge something someone else did. Could have printable certificates etc
item.summary: Could a DLT foster a X-Gov social capital data exchange?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comment._: Perfect candidate for DLT!

The reason I thought this story really suited DLT is because it reminded me of a fictional form of currency from a sci-fi book. Just thought it was interesting, and thought DLT could be a fun way to implement the concept:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whuffie

In the novel Down and Out in the Magic Kingdom, industrial-era economic constraints and scarcity-management regimes have been made obsolete by technology: Whuffie has replaced money, providing an esteem- and admiration-rewarding motivation for people to do useful and creative things. A person's Whuffie is a general measurement of his or her overall reputation and is gained (or lost) according to a person's favorable (or unfavorable) actions. Public opinion determines which actions are favorable or unfavorable. The Whuffie of one who rudely pushes past others may suffer, as she falls within the disapprobation of those pushed, or witnesses of the event. A much-loved symphony, on the other hand, continues to earn the composer Whuffie as more people enjoy it.

I'd hate to live in a society based on such a currency, but it makes for an interesting thought experiment (or a loose approach to implementing a reputation system).

item.title: [IN-4] Can DLT such as Multichain help improve CPSe?
item.description:
The current project is looking at ways to move Oracle Financial (The big red box) into a wrapped state so that it can be replaced easily, potentially in some way by the Blockchain.

Our discussion centred around the proposition that a Blockchain would start as a permanent record of what transactions had taken place, which would allow the easy distribution to other external departments as well as other systems.

They originally thought that Blockchain would enable actual payments but we helped them see how they would still need the banking system, but that it would be possible to include records on the Blockchain that show what transactions completed and which did not.

Their ask of us was that we created a POC but I would have expected them to have specific funding for this purpose so we would support them with our knowledge and expertise in investigating smaller component use cases around the Blockchain.

Learning Oracle Financials is not something we would be looking to do.
item.summary: Can DLT such as Multichain help improve CPSe?

$.description: This issue is being actively worked on at the moment by the assignee.

comment._:
Communication received today indicates that the CPSe team will be looking at standing up an internal MultiChain on their own systems over the next month, they will hopefully look at integration with their new systems after that.

The focus currently is in working their existing systems into a state in which they can move forward with their plans.
HIgh level diagram of what is proposed for CPSe

item.title: [IN-9] Could BigChainDB provide an alternative path to migrating existing technical services on to a microservice architecture?
item.description:
Summary

BigChainDB is a SQL database that uses the distributed characteristics of Blockchains to ensure that all nodes hold exactly the same data structures. This could mean that it is possible to replace SQL server with a local BigChainDB node and replace functional parts of an existing system with microservices.
item.summary: Could BigChainDB provide an alternative path to migrating existing technical services on to a microservice architecture?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-112] Can Two Factor Authentication - for access to data stored on TPM enabled devices - use external devices such as mobile phones rather than USB sticks?
item.description:
TPM enabled devices provide a means to authenticate with server based systems by means of two factor authentication. The two forms of authentication in this scenario are the TPM enabled device and the users credentials. Access to server based systems the TPM enabled device takes on the roles of the security card.

For information stored on the device with the TPM chip installed however you are not using two factor authentication in its known form which should involve 2 separate devices.

Could this system be integrated with an SMS authentication system as part of microsoft passport and hello or can google authenticator be integrated.

Additionally could GOV.UK Verify provide two factor authentication.
item.summary: Can Two Factor Authentication - for access to data stored on TPM enabled devices - use external devices such as mobile phones rather than USB sticks?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-106] Can smart mirrors change how employees of the department gain access to critical information?
item.description:
With any large organisation there will always be challenges in getting information out to every employee, so any ways to improve of dissemination of important or critical messages are worthy of exploration.

Enter: smart mirrors.

Could smart mirrors be used in place of existing mirrors in restrooms around the organisation? Any employee using the facilities will have access to information deemed important. The mirror could display pan-organisation information and/or building specific information. This could complement other channels of communication, such as email. It may even encourage more people to wash their hands after using the facilities.
item.summary: Can smart mirrors change how employees of the department gain access to critical information?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-105] Is the organisation following Reactive principles and if not, can they be applied to improve software production
item.description:
Reactive programming comprises a set of principles and practices to facilitate the production of scalable, resilient and failure tolerant software.

The core tenets:

  • Elasticity
  • Responsiveness
  • Resilience
  • Message-driven

See: http://www.reactivemanifesto.org/
item.summary: Is the organisation following Reactive principles and if not, can they be applied to improve software production

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-103] Could a combination of advanced type systems with Theorem Provers improve the security or reduce the error margins in processing systems?
item.description:
Theorem Provers provide a far more robust and advanced testing framework that is designed to prove that a system can do what it is claimed. They allow you to prove that a process would be secure and prove that a computation does what it is supposed to do.

  • https://leanprover.github.io/tutorial/

When combined with a type system such as F* (star) provides it is possible to describe very complex computations and prove that they do what they are believed to do.

  • http://fstar-lang.org
  • https://github.com/Z3Prover/z3
  • https://github.com/leanprover/
item.summary: Could a combination of advanced type systems with Theorem Provers improve the security or reduce the error margins in processing systems?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-102] Could Lambda architectures provide a more elastic real-time processing ecosystem for handling service request load whilst reducing costs?
item.description:
• http://lambda-architecture.net/
  • https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/

Lambda architectures provide real time scalable processing power that adapt to capacity requirements. Currently they are focused on the processing of real-time data in the analytics space, but they open up the opportunity to update and modify state based on real time information as it arrives.

  • Static content publishing can be enabled by only publishing documents and data affected by events.
  • Ontologies could provide real-time intelligent data properties based on known facts
  • Microservices based on lambda architectures could automatically scale to cope with unexpected peaks in requests
item.summary: Could Lambda architectures provide a more elastic real-time processing ecosystem for handling service request load whilst reducing costs?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-101] Could a new service request protocol like GraphQL enable more reuse of microservices and enable faster prototyping and development lifecycles?
item.description:
GraphQL is a data query language and runtime designed and used at Facebook to request and deliver data to mobile and web apps since 2012. It has the potential to reduce the number of read services required due to the flexibility of the services it enables.

  • DECLARATIVE Query responses are decided by the client rather than the server. A GraphQL query returns exactly what a client asks for and no more.
  • COMPOSITIONAL A GraphQL query itself is a hierarchical set of fields. The query is shaped just like the data it returns. It is a natural way for product engineers to describe data requirements.
  • STRONG-TYPED A GraphQL query can be ensured to be valid within a GraphQL type system at development time allowing the server to make guarantees about the response. This makes it easier to build high-quality client tools.

We believe that GraphQL represents a novel way of structuring the client-server contract. Servers publish a type system specific to their application, and GraphQL provides a unified language to query data within the constraints of that type system. That language allows product developers to express data requirements in a form natural to them: a declarative and hierarchal one.

This is a liberating platform for product developers. With GraphQL, no more contending with ad hoc endpoints or object retrieval with multiple roundtrips to access server data; instead an elegant, hierarchical, declarative query dispatched to a single endpoint. No more frequent jumps between client and server development environments to do experimentation, or to change or create views of existing data; instead experiments are done and new views are built within a native, client development environment exclusively. No more shuffling unstructured data from ad hoc endpoints into business objects; instead, you have a powerful, introspective type system that serves as a platform for tool building.

Product developers are free to focus on their client software and requirements while rarely leaving their development environment. They can more confidently support shipped clients as a system evolves; and they are using a protocol designed to operate well within the constraints of mobile applications. Product developers can query for exactly what they want, in the way they think about it, across their entire application's data model.
item.summary: Could a new service request protocol like GraphQL enable more reuse of microservices and enable faster prototyping and development lifecycles?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-95] Could DLT provide a better way to validate the quality of job seekers and job advertisers?
item.description:
It is understood that job seekers may not turn up for committed opportunities to work and equally job advertisers may game the system and offer positions that are either tenuous, duplicated or poorly described. The only way to know what is currently going on is through feedback from both parties and a decision as to which party is being most honest.

Could a DLT such as a Blockchain be used as trusted distributed record of attendance by job seekers and validation of job offerings by job advertisers?
item.summary: Could DLT provide a better way to validate the quality of job seekers and job advertisers?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-94] Could SKOS help improve Job Search capabilities for job seekers and consultants?
item.description:
Simple Knowledge Organisational System (SKOS) provides an ontology that can be applied to graph data to enhance a search be narrowing and expanding terms with it documents.

Could this be used to help job seekers and job advertisers identify larger or better groups of candidates to suit their individual needs.

e.g.

"Java Programmer" is a narrow form of "Programmer"
"Java Programming Language" is a narrower form of "Object Oriented Programming Language"
"C# Programming Language" is a narrower form of "Object Oriented Programming Language"
"Java Programmer" has an understanding of "Java Programming Language"
"C# Programmer" has an understanding of "C# Programming Language"

based on this knowledge a request for "Object Oriented Programmer" would find "Object Oriented Programmers" first but could fall back on "Java Programmers", "C# Programmers" and possibly "Programmers" if needed
item.summary: Could SKOS help improve Job Search capabilities for job seekers and consultants?

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [IN-57] Vimeo video for learning and training
item.description:
• UC and all the other digital service releases are/ will be happening on a fortnightly basis – we need staff to be able to view videos on their PCs in order that they are kept up to speed on the changes to the IT systems that they are working off. Currently changes are communicated on paper and training is done in face to face groups, via elearning or now lync. This alone is not sustainable if we want to land the agile approach to IT development properly into the business.
  • When we are delivering strategic communications we need to have a better video capability that staff can view from their pcs. Many of the major projects depend on significant culture change and videos play a significant role here.
  • General training – we can run videos in classes off laptops (not on the network) but we really want to be able to store videos on the network for staff to be able to play post learning - so if they forget their learning, the videos can be sourced by them to remind them.
item.summary: Vimeo video for learning and training

$.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
